intro: Osbeckia octandra, commonly known as the broadleaf willow-herb, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed soils and can be found in meadows, stream banks, and forest edges. It has alternate, ovate to lanceolate leaves and produces small, yellowish flowers in racemes. Its botanical characteristics make it adaptable to various environmental conditions, contributing to its widespread distribution.
